{{c1::Sepsis}}:  life-threatening organ dysfunction caused by a dysregulated host response to infection

 Clinical suspicion of infection plus one of following presentations:
 Unwell patient at risk of {{c1::neutropenia}}; 
 Clinical evidence of new onset organ failure: acute altered mental status, oliguria/anuria, non-{{c1::blanching}} rash, hypotension, hypoxia, etc.
 ≥ 2 {{c1::SIRS}} criteria plus ≥ 1 co-morbidities eg. COPD, DM, chronic liver/renal disease, cancer, advanced age, immunosuppressive Rx, major surgery/trauma, etc.

neutropenia: low neutrophils
non-blanching: don't disappear with pressure

{{c1::Infective endocarditis}}: Bacterial (or fungal) infection of a heart valve or area of endocardium

Pathogenesis
Host factors
•Pre-existing valvular {{c1::lesions}} eg. congenital, rheumatic fever, aortic sclerosis in elderly patients
•Congenital cardiac abnormalities causing {{c1::turbulent}} blood flows.
•Prosthetic {{c1::valves}}

Risks for bacteraemia
•Poor oral hygiene (dental/gingival conditions) – {{c1::viridans}} streptococci, etc.
•Invasive procedures / intravascular lines – {{c1::staphyl}}ococci, etc.
•Deep seated infections, etc.

Characteristics of infecting organisms:
• Virulence of organism eg. {{c1::S. aureus}} -> acute course
• Ability to adhere and colonise damaged endothelium or prosthetic surfaces
• Streptococci, staphylococci & enterococci (ie. Gram{{c1::-positive}} cocci) together are responsible for >{{c1::80}}% of cases.

complications of endocarditis
Local
•{{c1::Valvular}} destruction and incompetence
• Valvular root {{c1::abscess}}
• Cardiopulmonary complications eg. ventricular hypertrophy, heart failure, pulmonary oedema

Metastatic
 Hands/feet: splinter haemorrhages, nail-fold infarcts, {{c1::Osler}}’s nodes, {{c1::Janeway}} lesions, etc.
 Eyes: Retina - {{c1::Roth}} spots; conjunctival haemorrhages
 Deep organs:
 Infarction – {{c1::splenic and renal}} infarcts, etc.
 Abscess formation – bone/joint; brain abscesses; pulmonary embolism/abscesses; etc.

Other
• Acute {{c1::renal}} failure -secondary to IE or to treatment – aminoglycosides and/or glycopeptides
• Mycotic aneurysms
• Death
Vegetation is a hallmark of endocarditis

Subacute native valve endocarditis
is {{c1::less}} aggressive

 Risk factors:
•Congenital heart disease (high to lower pressure gradients greatest risk)
•Rheumatic {{c1::Heart}} Disease
•{{c1::Mitral}} valve prolapse
•Degenerative valve lesions

{{c1::Hematopoiesis}} is a term describing the formation and development of blood cells.

Hematopoiesis begins as early as the {{c1::19th}} day after fertilization in the {{c1::yolk sac of the embryo}}
-Only {{c1::erythrocytes}} are made
-The RBCs contain unique fetal{{c1::hemoglobins}}
-At about 6 weeks of gestation, yolk sac production of erythrocytes decreases and production of RBCs in the human embryo itself begins.

-The fetal {{c1::liver}} becomes the chief site of blood cell production
-The {{c1::spleen, kidney, thymus, and lymph nodes}} (4) serve as minor sites of blood cell production
-the bone marrow becomes the primary site of hematopoiesis at about {{c1::6 months of gestation}} and continues throughout life.
-When the bone marrow becomes the chief site of hematopoiesis, leukocyte and thrombocyte production become more prominent.

-Hematopoiesis in the bone marrow is called {{c1::medullary haematopoiesis}}
-Hematopoiesis in areas other then the bone marrow is called {{c1::extramedullary hematopoiesis}}

-Extramedullary hematopoiesis may occur in fetal hematopoietic tissue (liver and spleen) of an adult when the bone marrow cannot meet the physiologic needs of the tissues.  This can lead to hepatomegaly and/or splenomegaly (increase in size of the liver and/or spleen because of increased functions in the organs).
The mononuclear phagocytic system also called reticular endothelial system, RES) is involved in {{c1::cellular destruction}} and it includes (3)

-Circulating blood monocytes
-Fixed macrophages in the bone marrow, liver, spleen, and lymph nodes
-Free macrophages
¢These cells are involved in:
Engulfing particulate matter
Processing of antigens for lymphocyte presentation
Removal of damaged or senescent (aged) cells

{{c1::Spleen}} – contains the largest collection of lymphocytes and mononuclear phagocytes in the body.
Name its 3 functions

The spleen functions in:
¢Filtering and destruction of senescent (aged) or damaged RBCS – also called culling
¢Removal of particles (are found in some types of anemia) from RBC membranes – also called pitting – this causes a decrease in the surface to volume ratio of the RBC resulting in the formation of spherocytes (more on this later)
¢Enforcing close contact of blood borne antigens with lymphocytes and phagocytic cells – this is more important in children particularly in protection of the host from infections due to enveloped organisms

-Sequestering {{c1::1/3}} of the platlet mass – in massive splenomegaly this can lead to peripheral {{c1::thrombocytopenia (decrease in platlets in the peripheral blood)}}

-After a {{c1::splenectomy (removal of the spleen)}}, RBC inclusions and abnormal RBC shapes are seen.  Culling is taken over by the {{c1::liver}} which is less effective in performing all of the {{c1::splenic}} functions

{{c1::Hypersplenism (splenomegaly)}} – in a number of conditions the spleen may become enlarged and through an exaggeration of its normal functions of filtering, and destruction and sequestering, it may cause {{c1::anemia (may be caused by decreased RBCs)}}, {{c1::leukopenia (decreased WBCs)}}, or {{c1::thrombocytopenia}} or combinations of these cytopenias.  When all three cell types are decreased this is called pancytopenia.

There are two types of hypersplenism:

-Primary – no underlying disease has been identified
-Secondary – caused by an underlying disorder such as:
Inflammatory diseases
Infectious diseases
Blood disorders that cause compensatory or workload hypertrophy of the organ such as:
  Abnormal blood cells, antibody coated blood cells, hereditary spherocytosis, idiopathic throbocytopenic purpura (ITP)
The effects of these are relieved by splenectomy

In a normal adult, ½ of the bone marrow is hematopoietically active ({{c1::red}} marrow) and ½ is inactive, fatty marrow ({{c1::yellow}} marrow).

True

-In certain pathologic states the bone marrow can increase its activity to 5-10X its normal rate.
¢ When this happens, the bone marrow is said to be hyperplastic because it replaces the yellow marrow with red marrow.

Mature blood cells have a limited life span and with the exception of {{c1::lymphocytes}}, are incapable of self-renewal.

-Replacement of peripheral hematopoietic cells is a function of the {{c1::pluripotential (totipotential)}} stem cells found in the {{c1::bone marrow}}

-Hematopoietic cells can be divided into three cellular compartments based on maturity:
-{{c1::Pluripotential}} stem cell capable of self-renewal and differentiation into all blood cell lines.
-{{c1::Committed proginator}} stem cells destined to develop into distinct cell lines
-{{c1::Mature cells}} with specialized functions

A. Occurs when incompatible RBC’s are transfused into a recipient who has pre-formed antibodies (usually ABO or Rh), Antibodies activate the complement system, Symptoms occur within minutes of starting the transfusion

B. Rise in patient temperature >1°C (associated with transfusion without other fever precipitating factors), Occurs with approx 1% of PRBC transfusions and approx 20% of Plt transfusions

C. May be due to plasma proteins or blood preservative/anticoagulant, Best characterized with IgA given to an IgA deficient patients with anti-IgA antibodies 

D. Clinical syndrome similar to ARDS, Occurs 1-6 hours after receiving plasma-containing blood products, Caused by WBC antibodies present in donor blood that result in pulmonary leukostasis

E. Coagulopathy may occur, Coagulopathy is caused by failure to replace plasma

{{c1::Ischaemia}}:restriction in blood supply (from either reduced arterial flow or reduced venous drainage) which causes oxygen deprivation and results in tissue damage.

-However, sometimes, cells proceed to die after blood flow resumes: {{c1::reperfusion injury}}
Why (2)?

1.Re-oxygenation increases generation of oxygen free radicals causing new damage
2.Production of cytokines recruits circulating neutrophils to reperfused tissue resulting in inflammation.

{{c1::Infarction}}: An area of ischaemic necrosis caused by occlusion of either the arterial supply or the venous drainage in a particular tissue. 

Vast majority of infarcts due to thrombotic /embolic events, almost all due to {{c1::arterial}} occlusion

•{{c1::Venous thrombosis}} more often induces venous obstruction and congestion rather than infarction.
What are the exceptions?

Exception: organs with a single venous outflow channel,
e.g. testis or ovary

Which is white vs. red infarct?
A With venous occlusions (testis, ovary).

B In loose tissues such as lung which allow blood to collect in the infarcted zone.

C Occur with arterial occlusions or in solid organs (e.g. heart, spleen, kidney) where the solidity of the tissue limits the amount of haemorrhage that can seep into the area of ischaemic necrosis from adjoining capillary beds.

D In tissues with dual circulations (e.g. lung, liver) allowing flow of blood from the unobstructed vessel into the necrotic zone (but not enough perfusion to restore the ischaemic tissues).

-Takes a while for changes to be demonstrable {{c1::histologically}}.

Schema of Atherogenesis
•Minor endothelial damage, Name 4 causes {{c1::(turbulence, relative anoxia, hypertension, oxidation or glycation)}}
•{{c1::LDL}} particles cross the damaged endothelium
•Circulating monocytes attracted by the damaged endothelium & enter the {{c1::subendothelial}} space.
•LDL particles in the artery wall are {{c1::oxidised}} by oxygen free radicals name 4 sources {{c1::(present in cigarette smoke, formed during glycation reactions, generated by macrophages deliberately to kill bacteria or leaking from various oxidative pathways)}}
•Oxidised LDL is taken up rapidly by macrophages (AKA {{c1::foam cells}})
Schema of Atherogenesis

Schema of Atherogenesis
•Collagen elaborated by {{c1::fibroblasts}} comes to overlie the foam cells, which undergo necrosis or apoptosis
•This results in the formation of a pool of extracellular {{c1::cholesterol}} trapped beneath a {{c1::fibrous}} cap.
•At the shoulder of the {{c1::atheromatous}} lesion active foam cell formation continues & the lesion advances across the inner surface of the artery.
•Plaques can either obstruct blood flow resulting in ischaemia to the peripheral tissue or rupture with thrombus formation at the site of {{c1::the cap}} leading to {{c1::peripheral}} infarction.

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
¡Secondary hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is caused by conditions such as {{c1::hyper}}tension and aortic {{c1::stenosis}}

¡Primary hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM or often called HOCM (“hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy”) is a {{c1::genetic}} condition caused by mutations in genes encoding {{c1::sarcomeric}} proteins

HCM: Pathogenesis
¡Caused by mutations in any one of several genes that encode {{c1::sarcomeric}} proteins (>400 mutations in 9 different genes)

¡Most common mutation is in the gene encoding {{c1::β-myosin heavy}} chain

¡Usually autosomal {{c1::dominant}}

¡Prognosis varies and correlates with the specific mutations involved

Gross: Massive myocardial hypertrophy, predominantly {{c1::septal}}
Usually no {{c1::ventricular}} dilatation

Microscopic: ¡{{c1::Myocyte}} hypertrophy ++
¡{{c1::Myofibre}} disarray
¡Interstitial and replacement fibrosis

In addition, ~25% of pts. with HCM have {{c1::dynamic obstruction}} to the left ventricular outflow 

¡Basic physiologic abnormality is reduced {{c1::stroke}} volume due to impaired diastolic {{c1::filling}} which results from reduced {{c1::chamber}} size and {{c1::compliance}} of the massively hypertrophied LV

Clinical features
¡Ejection {{c1::systolic}} murmur
¡SOB on exertion
¡Chest pain
¡{{c1::Arrhythmias}} → sudden death (sudden death in young athletes)
¡Treat with {{c1::β-blockers}}

Restrictive cardiomyopathy
-primary {{c1::decrease}} in ventricular compliance, resulting in impaired ventricular filling during {{c1::diastole}}
-Idiopathic, or associated with diseases such as radiation {{c1::fibrosis}}, amyloidosis, sarcoidosis

morphology
Gross: Ventricles ~ normal size or slightly {{c1::increased}}; no ventricular {{c1::dilatation}}, {{c1::myocardium}} is firm, may be {{c1::atrial}} dilatation
¡Microscopy: Patchy/diffuse {{c1::interstitial}} fibrosis, may be able to determine specific {{c1::aetiology - thing causing it}}
Idiopathic: relating to or denoting any disease or condition which arises spontaneously or for which the cause is unknown.

amyloidosis
-Characterised by extracellular deposition of {{c1::protein}} fragments
-Cardiac amyloidosis may arise in isolation or along with systemic amyloidosis (e.g. senile cardiac amyloidosis: good prognosis
amyloidosis: protein, called amyloid, builds up in your organs and interferes with their normal function.

haemochromatosis
Iron deposition in the heart is highlighted by a {{c1::Prussian blue/Perl’s stain}} which stains iron blue

myocarditis
¡Gross: the heart is often {{c1::normal}}
¡Microscopy: {{c1::lymphocytic}} infiltrate (may be patchy), focal {{c1::myocyte}} necrosis

Clincial
¡Asymptomatic
¡May have complete recovery
¡Heart failure, arrhythmias, sudden death
¡Late complication: {{c1::dilated}} cardiomyopathy

PERICARDITIS
3 causes and 2 example per cause
Is it usaully chronic or acute? {{c1::acute}}

Morphology
¡Serous
¡Fibrinous/serofibrinous
¡Purulent
¡Haemorrhagic
¡Caseous
¡Chronic-
pericarditis/healed pericarditis: fibrous thickenings/adhesions

Non-modifiable:  
•Increasing Age

Modifiable
•Cigarette Smoking

• Hyperlipidaemia (HDL<35mg/dl LDL>160mg/dl )

Alcohol has a protective effect (possibly)
Oestrogen has a protective effect but drops after menopause

Homocysteine is a common amino acid in your blood. You get it mostly from eating meat.

Atherosclerosis
•Acute Myocardial Infarction and Stroke
•{{c1::50}}% of all deaths
•Males > Females
•Age Related
•Elastic and Muscular {{c1::Arteries}}
•Begins in, primarily involves, {{c1::intima}}

Response to Injury theory – Atherosclerosis is a chronic {{c1::inflammatory}} response of the arterial wall initiated by some form of injury to the vessel wall

Steps
{{c1::Endothelial}} cell injury 
-> lead to {{c1::endothelial}} dysfunction 
->Monocytes (CD{{c1::8}}, {{c1::CD4}}) adhere to abnormal endothelium (adhesion molecules) & migrate into vessel wall.
->Secrete {{c1::Cytokines}} (Growth factors) 
->Attract Smooth muscle cells & Activate {{c1::macrophages}}


•Early lesion = {{c1::Fatty Streak}}
•Advanced lesion = {{c1::Fibrous Plaque}}

Fatty Streaks
•Confined to {{c1::intima}}
•Composed of lipid filled {{c1::foam}} cells.
•Flat, no blood flow disturbance.
•Multiple 1mm yellow spots, coalesce into streaks >1cm


Steps
Fatty Streaks enlarge and Disrupt Endothelial Surface
->Platelets {{c1::adhere}}
->Platelets release {{c1::PDGF}}
->More Smooth Muscle {{c1::Proliferation}}

Injured Endothelial Cells and Macrophages      Produce {{c1::Free Radicals}}
 ->Oxidise {{c1::LDL}} 
        - {{c1::Chemotactic}} for Monocytes
        - Stimulates release of {{c1::growth factors}}  
        - Neutralised by Antioxidants
-{{c1::collagen}} synthesis
Oxidised LDL: More Atherogenic

{{c1::Intimal}} plaque:Central aggregation of {{c1::foam}} cells, some of which have died and released lipid , surrounded by smooth muscle cells, with connective tissue on {{c1::intimal}} aspect

Plaques can undergo disruption, with superimposed {{c1::thrombus}}, rupture ---  known as complicated (vulnerable) plaque leads to {{c1::MI}}, {{c1::stroke}}

Atherosclerosis
Usual sites
•Develops in Areas of {{c1::Damage / Turbulence}}
•{{c1::Abdominal}} Aorta
•{{c1::Coronary}} Arteries
•{{c1::Popliteal}} artery
•{{c1::Descending}} Thoracic Aorta
•Internal {{c1::Carotid}} Artery
•Circle of {{c1::Willis}}

Complications
Obstruction:enlargement of atheroma, hemorrhage into atheroma, formation of thrombus
Embolism :infarcts
Aneurysm: Rupture

Organ Specific Complications (give the organs blood supply)
•{{c1::Coronary Arteries}}: Angina, Myocardial Infarct
•{{c1::Peripheral Vascular Disease}} – Peripheral ischaemia
•{{c1::Circle of Willis/ Vertebrobasilar/ Internal Carotids}}: Stroke, TIAs
•{{c1::Renal Arteries}}: Hypertension (Secondary)
•{{c1::Coeliac, Sup./Inf. Mesenterics}}: Ischaemia and Infarction of Intestine

Coronary Artery Disease
•Left Coronary Artery: LAD, LCA
•Right Coronary Artery
•Ischaemic Heart Disease (IHD)
•Manifestations: Angina pectoris, Acute myocardial infarction, Sudden cardiac death syndrome, Chronic IHD, Cardiac arrhythmias

Which side of the heart is dominant (give percent of population)?
What is the most common cause of death?

LAD - left ant. desc.
LCA - left circum. artery

Right dominant = 90% of pop.
•Ischaemic Heart Disease (IHD) is the most common cause of death

Myocardial Infarction (MI)
•Necrosis (death) of part of myocardium due to loss of blood supply (occlusion/ vasospasm)
2 types
•{{c1::Transmural}} – involves full thickness
•{{c1::Subendocardial}} – limited to {{c1::inner 1/3}} of wall

Loss of blood supply to myocardium
->Cessation of {{c1::aerobic glycolysis}}
->Accumulation of {{c1::lactic}} acid
->Cell death ( {{c1::myocyte}} necrosis) 

•Outcome depends on
   - Location/severity of occlusion
   - {{c1::Duration}} of occlusion (thrombolysis, angioplasty)
   - {{c1::collateral}} circulation
  - BP, heart rate

Presents with {{c1::retrosternal}} chest pain ( can be referred pain to left arm/jaw/abdomen), sudden weakness/ collapse, sudden death
“{{c1::Silent}} MI” occurs in elderly /diabetic patients
Cell death leads to release of cytoplasmic proteins into serum (Troponin) which can be measured to confirm diagnosis)

Histological Changes in MI
•0-12 hours – {{c1::None}}
•12-24hrs – {{c1::Pyknosis}} of nuclei, early neutrophilic infiltrate
•1- 3 days – Necrosis:- Loss of nuclei, neutrophilic infiltrate
•3-7 days – Macrophages, phagocytosis
•7-14 days –{{c1::granulation}} tissue formation
•2- 8 weeks – {{c1::collagen}} deposition
•> 2 months - scar
